newsitem.title: USA: Stocks tumble as profit-taking halts three-day rally.
newsitem.headline: Stocks tumble as profit-taking halts three-day rally.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks ran into a wall of selling Wednesday as profit-taking halted the market's three-session comeback after last week's headlong fall.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 45.32 points at 6,563.84. Last week, the market tumbled 215 points on interest-rate worries.
In the broader market, declining issues led advances 1,271 to 1,209 on active volume of 451 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
Technology and financial stocks, two groups that had paced the market's rally, were the hardest hit.
"Today we saw some giveback in the techs as well as the banks," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd.
"You'll see these stocks run up and then tend to give ground before the earnings," he said. Banks are among the first companies to report their results each quarter.
The first-quarter earnings reporting season will get underway in earnest next week, and it should last until the end of the month.
While many analysts generally view the stock market's recent woes as part of a correction, there is mounting evidence the pullback is taking an toll on investors.
According to a newly released survey by financial services company Quick & Reilly, 39 percent of investors described themselves as bullish, down from 58 percent in January.

Those expressing a bearish market outlook rose to 31 percent, up from 20 percent three months ago. The survey showed the prevailing investor mood as "conservatism rather than panic", Quick & Reilly said.

The stock market's recent ills also were reflected in a $2.4 billion drop in assets at Fidelity Investments' flagship Magellan Fund. The firm said Magellan assets fell to $51.4 billion at the end of March from $53.8 billion in February.

Fidelity also said Magellan boosted the share of assets in stocks to 95.5 percent at the end of February -- the most recent month for which figures are available -- from 93.5 percent a month earlier, shrinking its cash and bond holdings.

There were pockets of strength in the market. Dow index component Procter & Gamble Co. jumped 4 to 119-3/4 after announcing it would acquire Tambrands Inc. for $50 per share in cash, or some $1.85 billion.
Tambrands, which had gained in recent sessions on rumours of the deal, rose 2 to 48-1/8.
Transportation stocks were higher, paced by rallies in railroad companies CSX Corp. and Norfolk Southern Corp., in the wake of their agreement to split up Conrail Inc.
CSX climbed 1-1/2 to 45-3/4 and Norfolk Southern gained 1/4 to 87-1/8. Conrail rose 3/8 to 113-3/4.
HBO & Co. rallied 1-3/4 to 51-3/8 after the health care information company's first quarter earnings beat Wall Street estimates.
The Nasdaq Composite index lost 7.94 points to 1,249.43.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 5.52 to 760.60. The American Stock Exchange index was up 1.56 to 562.98.
The NYSE Composite index of all listed common stocks fell 2.02 to 400.29. The average share was down 21 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of NYSE, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 7,268.605 down 37.144 or 0.51 percent.
